content: Let L\mathscr{L}L be a non-empty set and let Γ∪Δ⊆L\Gamma\cup \Delta\subseteq \mathscr{L}Γ∪Δ⊆L. Does there exist any function μΓΔ:L→{0,1}{\mu_\Gamma^{\Delta}}:\mathscr{L}\to\{0,1\}μΓΔ​:L→{0,1} such that for all Σ⊆L\Sigma\subseteq \mathscr{L}Σ⊆L μΓΔ(Σ)⊆{1}{\mu_\Gamma^{\Delta}}(\Sigma)\subseteq \{1\}μΓΔ​(Σ)⊆{1} iff Γ⊆Σ⊆Δ\Gamma\subseteq \Sigma\subseteq \DeltaΓ⊆Σ⊆Δ? (This seems to be a very natural generalisation of the characteristic function, but I can't seem to find anything in literature , nor can I come up with something on my own.)

So μΓΔ(Σ)\mu_\Gamma^\Delta(\Sigma)μΓΔ​(Σ) exists only when Γ=∅\Gamma = \emptysetΓ=∅. For Γ=∅\Gamma = \emptysetΓ=∅, take μΓΔ\mu_\Gamma^\DeltaμΓΔ​ to be the characteristic function of Δ\DeltaΔ. If you want the condition to include at least one Σ\SigmaΣ which is a proper subset of Γ\GammaΓ, then it's impossible, because μΓΔ(Σ)⊈{1}\mu_\Gamma^\Delta(\Sigma) \not\subseteq \{1\}μΓΔ​(Σ)⊆{1} would imply that there exists x∈Σ⊂Γx \in \Sigma \subset \Gammax∈Σ⊂Γ with μΓΔ(x)=0\mu_\Gamma^\Delta(x) = 0μΓΔ​(x)=0, and then also μΓΔ(Γ)⊈{1}\mu_\Gamma^\Delta(\Gamma) \not\subseteq \{1\}μΓΔ​(Γ)⊆{1}.

I think I agree: clearly any element outside Σ\SigmaΣ must take the value 000, but even if we send everything in Σ\SigmaΣ to 111, the function has no way to tell if an element of Γ\GammaΓ is missing from a subset.

Yes. In fact, if we choose any Γ\GammaΓ which is not a singleton set then we will obtain a contradiction as follows. Suppose such a function exists. Choose any Σ⊆L\Sigma\subseteq \mathscr{L}Σ⊆L such that Γ⊆Σ⊆Δ\Gamma\subseteq \Sigma\subseteq \DeltaΓ⊆Σ⊆Δ. Since Γ⊆Σ⊆Δ\Gamma\subseteq \Sigma\subseteq \DeltaΓ⊆Σ⊆Δ, μΓΔ(Σ)⊆{1}\mu^{\Delta}_{\Gamma}(\Sigma)\subseteq \{1\}μΓΔ​(Σ)⊆{1} - implying that μΓΔ(β)=1\mu^{\Delta}_{\Gamma}(\beta)=1μΓΔ​(β)=1 for all β∈Σ\beta\in \Sigmaβ∈Σ. But μΓΔ(β)=1\mu^{\Delta}_{\Gamma}(\beta)=1μΓΔ​(β)=1 implies that Γ⊆{β}⊆Δ\Gamma\subseteq \{\beta\}\subseteq \DeltaΓ⊆{β}⊆Δ. This is a contradiction since Γ\GammaΓ is not a singleton set.
